1143208588770500608.text: Today I called for the House to begin an impeachment inquiry into President Trump because there are moments for careful calculation, weighing political expediency & conflicting interests. And there moments for clarity and conviction. This is that moment. https://t.co/5aIv9hQSGZ

1143188554757083136.text: Read my full statement here: https://t.co/kwtXqsBNzl /12

1143188553884733442.text: There are moments for careful calculation. For weighing political expediency and conflicting interests. And there moments for clarity and conviction. This is that moment. /11

1143188553234550786.text: But, I believe an impeachment inquiry will be a fair airing and consideration of the facts that the American people must understand. /10

1143188552328593408.text: The American people should understand that opening an impeachment inquiry is not removal of the President. Given the behavior of the Senate, that outcome is probably out of the question. /9

1143188551431086081.text: Unless we restore respect for the law, respect for truth and respect for common decency, we cannot hope to solve any of our other pressing problems. /8

1143188550613123074.text: But look at where we are today.  Republicans in this chamber cheer or justify or stand woefully silent in the face of behavior for which they would have impeached a Democratic president many times over. Our best and most proven ideas cannot get even a hearing in the Senate. /7

1143188549837230085.text: Impeachment is divisive. The politics of impeachment are messy and uncertain, and might, in the short run, serve the President’s narrow political interests. /6

1143188549057089537.text: I have, until now, been conflicted about those interests. Impeachment, along with the right to declare war, is the most awesome power of Congress. /5

1143188548369244160.text: From the moment of his inauguration, this President has shown contempt for the truth, has attacked our institutions, and has ignored the Constitution he swore to defend. /4

1143188547635240963.text: But there are moments for calculation. For prudence, compromise and the careful weighing of competing interests. And there are moments for clarity and conviction. This is such a moment. /3

1143188546775322624.text: Those that know me know that I generally shy away from sharp partisanship in favor of the negotiation and compromise required for law to be made. /2

1143188546095853568.text: It is time for the House of Representatives to begin an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump. /1

1120499554015641601.text: @Viv__Savage @Juliess31 @MEPFuller Really? First of all, what is “right” is almost never obvious. And second, the House of Representatives exists to act on the will of the people (as understood by representatives). Are you proposing a different system?

1120499021825679360.text: @chrisbrad22 @TEE1031 @Juliess31 @MEPFuller Advocating with your representative is not ludicrous. It is at the very core of our democracy. Are you arguing that the way forward here is totally obvious? What if someone out there disagrees with you?

1120498140170342400.text: @FlyingMezerkis @MEPFuller Yes. I am a representative. And who do you think I represent? People. And don’t you think I (and all my colleagues) should be responsible about understanding what they (you) think?

1120497560718909440.text: @Mowkillnotill @whstancil Exactly! What I’ve been saying all night! Let’s gauge what citizens here and around the country want.

1120497384910401536.text: @jjwilson23 @whstancil Well I’ll ignore the personal attack at the end there and ask you if you think the American electorate today is the same as the electorate in 1973.

1120497167414845441.text: @TomNissley @MEPFuller Find me the “purely political” part in my statements. That was purely @MEPFuller putting words in my mouth. Not what I said or believe.

1120496908060045312.text: @kateinCT1 @Juliess31 @MEPFuller Well, threats are not the most persuasive form of argument, but if you read my tweets, you will see that I have spent the evening arguing for us to reflect on what our constituents want. Here and in swing states.

1120496095770152960.text: @BillyVonElds @RepDwightEvans And I’m sorry, play back for me what is disappointing to you. All I’ve said all night is that we should do some due diligence on public sentiment here. I’m kinda hung on that “Representative” part of my title.

1120495819042508800.text: @RacoonSquadron @ryannicholos @MEPFuller Ah. A response so thoughtful and considered that I can’t believe it’s on Twitter.

1120495553375363073.text: @ciaobellaalora @MEPFuller I’m not saying we don’t try. I’m saying that we consider public opinion. That is why this particular function rests with the legislature, not the judiciary, which is theoretically insulated from public opinion.

1120495239347699713.text: @TomNissley @MEPFuller Yeah. Except that I’m not saying any of that.

1120494638828335104.text: @ashtotheru @pwnedlib @MEPFuller I don’t think you’re reading very carefully. I’m not saying we don’t impeach or that we don’t do our duty. I am saying we should consider public sentiment. Like say, yours.

1120494450676051975.text: @Juliess31 @pwnedlib @MEPFuller I don’t think you’re reading very carefully. I’m not saying we don’t impeach or that we don’t do our duty. I am saying we should consider public sentiment. Like say, yours.

1120494150581878785.text: @FlyingMezerkis @MEPFuller So I don’t know where you are seeing me say we should ignore anything. I’m not arguing against impeachment. In fact I am arguing for taking our responsibility seriously by considering public sentiment.

1120493871396470784.text: @TEE1031 @Juliess31 @MEPFuller Again. I challenge you to find where in my tweets tonight I say we should not impeach or hold him accountable.

1120493538809208832.text: @ryannicholos @MEPFuller So I challenge you to find the part in my tweets tonight where I say we shouldn’t impeach. Either show that to me or change tack.

1120493297598959618.text: @BillyVonElds Ah. The ad hominem attack. Always a sign....

1120492384356319236.text: @williamg1 @MEPFuller That is a fair point. It is possible. We should consider that too.

1120492196950695941.text: @Juliess31 @MEPFuller Thought experiment: Let’s stipulate that Trump will not be removed by impeachment. And let’s stipulate the possibility that impeachment meaningfully increases his chance of re-election (something I don’t know right now). What do you do?

1120491584716529666.text: @ryannicholos @MEPFuller No. Which is why that particular function rests in the judiciary, not the legislature. But prosecutors make charge/no charge decisions every single day.

1120491250061328385.text: @MissingLynx @MEPFuller Not exactly what I’m saying. Historically, Congress has impeached, and will again. But nothing in the constitution forces Congress to impeach in a given circumstance. If you disagree, send me the language that forces Congress to do so.

1120490551848198145.text: @MEPFuller Where Matt, do I say it is “all political”? Seriously. I am a huge defender of the press. But it’s hard to do that when I take the time to engage with you and you mistate my argument. Or talk about my “look”. Are you trying to get at the truth here, or to stir the pot?

1120489972908404737.text: @kylelitke @MEPFuller No. And I’m not arguing that.

1120489812941733888.text: @williamg1 @MEPFuller I know the facts. And again, I’m not arguing for doing nothing. I’m arguing for acting in a smart and considered way.

1120489240335400960.text: @forkinshirtball @MEPFuller I know Twitter is a universe where logic is not important, but I’m not arguing for doing nothing, I’m arguing for doing what we do in a fully informed way.

1120488830900080640.text: @pwnedlib @MEPFuller I think you’re not reading it very carefully.

1120488738365345795.text: @selina3sticks @MEPFuller As a non lawyer, I couldn’t agree more.

1120488486124118018.text: @MEPFuller There is no explicit duty as there is conduct a census every 10 years. Congress decides if and when to impeach independent of the words of the constitution. That’s not controversial. It’s true. So it’s not unreasonable to try to understand where American sentiment is in deciding.

1120486186571784196.text: @MEPFuller Lordy. It’s not about a look. Duty is in quotes because the constitution imposes absolutely no obligation to impeach under any circumstance. It’s at the discretion of Congress. Kinda feels like you’re looking for a lot more fireworks than you’re going to find in this quarter.

1120485245227339776.text: @MEPFuller Like everything else a legislator does, there’s a mix of “knowing” and what public sentiment demands. Especially in the House, where we are called “Representative”. Impeachment could have been granted to SCOTUS, but instead, it was given to the part of our gov closest to people.

1120484036357623808.text: @MEPFuller I don’t think there’s an opposition between the two in this case. Impeachment is by design a political act, not a judicial or legal one. So public sentiment is as essential (probably more) as any implicit constitutional “duty”.

1120483458739048448.text: @MEPFuller Anyway, I was making an argument for care and consideration of facts and implications in however we choose to act. I expressed no view on how we should act.

1120482850967572482.text: @MEPFuller I made the case, because along with the will of my constituents, that would be something I would want to know before developing intense conviction. You know, be as informed as possible before acting?

1120482527163162624.text: @MEPFuller I don’t know what you heard, but I wasn’t forceful about not impeaching Trump (your words). I was forceful about making sure we had the best picture possible of how impeachment plays in Presidential swing states. Something I don’t know. See the diff?

1120481665120460800.text: @MEPFuller Which is different than “tamping down” the possibility of impeachment.

1120481357459787776.text: @MEPFuller No it wasn’t. Jim Himes argued that we should reflect on and consider the effect of impeachment proceedings on the chances of the President’s re-election, without prejudice. Because if he is not convicted by the Senate, 2020 is the next mechanism of accountability.
